path_1.title: For Love or Money (1963)
path_1.feeling: Broad, dated matchmaking antics left me cold.

path_1.title: Bourne Supremacy, The (2004)
path_1.feeling: Lean espionage beats the chaos, but the action gloss keeps me at arm’s length.

path_1.title: Dances with Wolves (1990)
path_1.feeling: Sweeping and sincere, but its sentimentality wears on me.

path_1.title: Ratatouille (2007)
path_1.feeling: Charming and flavorful, though its sweetness keeps me at a polite distance.

path_1.title: Mary Poppins (1964)
path_1.feeling: Inventive and warm, but the musical whimsy only goes so far for me.

path_1.title: The Artist (2011)
path_1.feeling: Affectionate homage with style, enjoyable if a touch slight.

path_1.title: Petrified Forest, The (1936)
path_1.feeling: Stagey but tense, with ideas and menace I appreciate.

path_1.title: They Shall Not Grow Old (2018)
path_1.feeling: Technical restoration impresses more than the overall insight.

path_1.title: Short Term 12 (2013)
path_1.feeling: Sincere and well acted, though its intimacy doesn’t fully floor me.

path_1.title: Out of the Past (1947)
path_1.feeling: Gorgeously fatalistic noir that hits my sweet spot.

path_1.title: Signs (2002)
path_1.feeling: Moody and intriguing setup, but the payoff feels too tidy.

path_1.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_1.feeling: Glossy and saccharine

path_1.title: Saboteur (1942)
path_1.feeling: Zippy Hitchcock set pieces, if lesser among his.

path_1.title: Rio Grande (1950)
path_1.feeling: Solid cavalry western with sturdy virtues, modest impact.

path_1.title: Secret Agent (1936)
path_1.feeling: Early Hitchcock intrigue that’s interesting more than gripping.

path_1.title: Anthropoid (2016)
path_1.feeling: Sober, tense, and morally bracing

path_1.title: Man Without a Star (1955)
path_1.feeling: Broad and blunt

path_1.title: Narrow Margin, The (1952)
path_1.feeling: Taut train-bound suspense right up my alley.

path_1.title: War Wagon, The (1967)
path_1.feeling: Light caper western fun, but thin for my taste.

path_1.title: Cat on a Hot Tin Roof (1958)
path_1.feeling: Electric performances drive a fierce, talky chamber piece.

path_1.title: Patch of Blue, A (1965)
path_1.feeling: Earnest and compassionate, if a bit tidy.

path_1.title: From Here to Eternity (1953)
path_1.feeling: Classic melodrama with grit and bite that holds up.

path_1.title: All Quiet on the Western Front (1930)
path_1.feeling: Stark, humane, and sobering

path_1.title: Dunkirk (2017)
path_1.feeling: Immersive craft, distant emotion

path_1.title: On the Waterfront (1954)
path_1.feeling: Powerful moral drama that lands with real weight.

path_1.title: Bedford Incident, The (1965)
path_1.feeling: Cold War tension well sustained, if somewhat schematic.

path_1.title: Few Good Men, A (1992)
path_1.feeling: Sharp courtroom fireworks scratch a familiar itch.

path_1.title: Roman Holiday (1953)
path_1.feeling: Effortless charm and wistfulness, warmly appealing.

path_1.title: Help, The (2011)
path_1.feeling: Well-meaning and polished, but a bit pat for me.

path_1.title: Boot, Das (Boat, The) (1981)
path_1.feeling: Claustrophobic, relentless, and absorbing—my kind of war picture.

path_2.title: For Love or Money (1963)
path_2.feeling: Frothy matchmaking farce with no bite—tiresome and weightless.

path_2.title: Bourne Supremacy, The (2004)
path_2.feeling: Lean, kinetic spy craft that thrills, though the shaky hyperactivity blunts the moral bite.

path_2.title: Dances with Wolves (1990)
path_2.feeling: Earnest and scenic but overlong and sentimental, its romanticism dulls the edge.

path_2.title: Ratatouille (2007)
path_2.feeling: Pleasant, deftly made, yet emotionally light for me—charming rather than resonant.

path_2.title: Mary Poppins (1964)
path_2.feeling: Sprightly and imaginative, but the sugar rush outweighs the substance.

path_2.title: The Artist (2011)
path_2.feeling: Elegant homage with charm and craft, if a touch slight beyond its conceit.

path_2.title: Petrified Forest, The (1936)
path_2.feeling: Stagey but tense hostage drama—philosophy and menace in a crisp desert bottle.

path_2.title: They Shall Not Grow Old (2018)
path_2.feeling: Technical restoration impresses

path_2.title: Short Term 12 (2013)
path_2.feeling: Quietly humane and clear-eyed, its compassion lands without false notes.

path_2.title: Out of the Past (1947)
path_2.feeling: Fatalistic, smoky noir—gorgeous and merciless

path_2.title: Signs (2002)
path_2.feeling: Moody build and family angst undone by thin payoff and hokey reveals.

path_2.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_2.feeling: Relentlessly saccharine pageant that smothers any real feeling.

path_2.title: Saboteur (1942)
path_2.feeling: Brisk man-on-the-run Hitchcock—spotty logic, steady momentum, solid set pieces.

path_2.title: Rio Grande (1950)
path_2.feeling: Sturdy Ford cavalry piece—serviceable, if emotionally muted for me.

path_2.title: Secret Agent (1936)
path_2.feeling: Early Hitchcock espionage with sparks of wit, but uneven and remote.

path_2.title: Anthropoid (2016)
path_2.feeling: Sober, tightly wound mission thriller with satisfying grit and stakes.

path_2.title: Man Without a Star (1955)
path_2.feeling: Broad, uneven western whose glib tone undercuts the conflict.

path_2.title: Narrow Margin, The (1952)
path_2.feeling: Taut, no-nonsense train noir—efficient, pressurized, and satisfying.

path_2.title: War Wagon, The (1967)
path_2.feeling: Breezy caper western, amiable but thin and low on tension.

path_2.title: Cat on a Hot Tin Roof (1958)
path_2.feeling: Blazing performances and claustrophobic family combat—articulate, bruising drama.

path_2.title: Patch of Blue, A (1965)
path_2.feeling: Sincere, tender social drama—moving if a bit neat.

path_2.title: From Here to Eternity (1953)
path_2.feeling: Polished wartime melodrama with bite, though the romance softens the punch.

path_2.title: All Quiet on the Western Front (1930)
path_2.feeling: Clear-eyed antiwar lament—spare, humane, and still harrowing.

path_2.title: Dunkirk (2017)
path_2.feeling: Immersive, precise survival piece—technically gripping, emotionally cool.

path_2.title: On the Waterfront (1954)
path_2.feeling: Morally thorny and muscular—powerful craftsmanship with real conscience.

path_2.title: Bedford Incident, The (1965)
path_2.feeling: Cold War tension well-rendered—procedural, relentless, and chilling.

path_2.title: Few Good Men, A (1992)
path_2.feeling: Sharply played courtroom chess—engaging, if a touch slick.

path_2.title: Roman Holiday (1953)
path_2.feeling: Graceful and charming, yet too airy to leave a lasting mark.

path_2.title: Help, The (2011)
path_2.feeling: Well-acted and earnest, but packaged a bit too neatly for the subject.

path_2.title: Boot, Das (Boat, The) (1981)
path_2.feeling: Claustrophobic, methodical submarine ordeal—superb tension and immersive detail.

path_2.title: For Love or Money (1963)
path_2.feeling: Glossy matchmaking fluff with no bite or tension for me.

path_2.title: Bourne Supremacy, The (2004)
path_2.feeling: Taut, propulsive spycraft, lighter on moral murk than I favor but cleanly executed.

path_2.title: Dances with Wolves (1990)
path_2.feeling: Earnest, expansive western epic whose sentiment softens its edge.

path_2.title: Ratatouille (2007)
path_2.feeling: Charming craft, but the whimsy only carries me so far.

path_2.title: Mary Poppins (1964)
path_2.feeling: Pleasant, airy confection—tuneful, if outside my usual tastes.

path_2.title: The Artist (2011)
path_2.feeling: Spry homage with graceful craft, if more clever pastiche than deep cut.

path_2.title: Petrified Forest, The (1936)
path_2.feeling: Talky, stage-bound hostage drama with flashes of fatalistic bite.

path_2.title: They Shall Not Grow Old (2018)
path_2.feeling: Technically striking restoration that engages more as artifact than narrative.

path_2.title: Short Term 12 (2013)
path_2.feeling: Quietly bruising character drama, empathetic and clear-eyed.

path_2.title: Out of the Past (1947)
path_2.feeling: Sumptuously fatalistic noir—cool, doomed, and morally tangled.

path_2.feeling: Glossy uplift and sugar rush I find cloying rather than stirring.

path_3.title: For Love or Money (1963)
path_3.feeling: Featherweight matchmaking contrivances left me cold.

path_3.title: Bourne Supremacy, The (2004)
path_3.feeling: Efficiently tense, but the shaky kineticism and amnesia beats kept me at arm’s length.

path_3.title: Dances with Wolves (1990)
path_3.feeling: Earnest and expansive, but its sentiment and sprawl dilute the moral bite I crave.

path_3.title: Ratatouille (2007)
path_3.feeling: Charming craft and theme, yet the whimsy and gloss keep it at a pleasant remove.

path_3.title: Mary Poppins (1964)
path_3.feeling: Inventive and amiable, though the sugar rush wears thin for me.

path_3.title: The Artist (2011)
path_3.feeling: Affectionate pastiche with graceful craft, if a touch lightweight emotionally.

path_3.title: Petrified Forest, The (1936)
path_3.feeling: Stagey but gripping hostage chamber piece with flavorful menace.

path_3.title: They Shall Not Grow Old (2018)
path_3.feeling: Technical restoration impresses, though the curatorial approach keeps me at a museum’s distance.

path_3.feeling: Quietly devastating character work with moral clarity and compassion.

path_3.title: Out of the Past (1947)
path_3.feeling: Fatalistic, smoky noir that aches with regret—irresistible.

path_3.feeling: Atmospheric dread and faith parable interest me, even as the payoff falters.

path_3.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)

path_3.title: Saboteur (1942)

path_3.title: Rio Grande (1950)
path_3.feeling: Solid Ford cavalry rhythms and family tensions, respectable rather than stirring.

path_3.title: Secret Agent (1936)
path_3.feeling: Early Hitchcock intrigue with ethical qualms, engaging but uneven.

path_3.title: Anthropoid (2016)
path_3.feeling: Sober, tense operation drama with admirable grit if limited depth.

path_3.title: Man Without a Star (1955)
path_3.feeling: Cornball tonal shifts and thin stakes made this range war a slog.

path_3.title: Narrow Margin, The (1952)
path_3.feeling: Lean, hard-nosed train noir that clicks with brisk economy.

path_3.title: War Wagon, The (1967)
path_3.feeling: Jaunty heist-western swagger that amuses more than it compels.

path_3.title: Cat on a Hot Tin Roof (1958)
path_3.feeling: Sultry, bruising performances and bottled-up truths hit satisfyingly hard.

path_3.title: Patch of Blue, A (1965)
path_3.feeling: Sincere, affecting social melodrama, modest in scope but humane.

path_3.title: From Here to Eternity (1953)
path_3.feeling: Handsome, affecting ensemble with credible moral undercurrents.

path_3.title: All Quiet on the Western Front (1930)
path_3.feeling: Unadorned, scathing antiwar clarity that still chills.

path_3.title: Dunkirk (2017)
path_3.feeling: Immaculate craft and nerve, yet its cool remove left me admiring more than feeling.

path_3.feeling: Moral awakening rendered with bruised intensity and superb control.

path_3.title: Bedford Incident, The (1965)
path_3.feeling: Taut Cold War brinkmanship with a chilling fatalism I appreciate.

path_3.title: Few Good Men, A (1992)
path_3.feeling: Rousing courtroom sparring and ethical fault lines kept me absorbed.

path_3.title: Roman Holiday (1953)
path_3.feeling: Effervescent and tender, though its lightness leaves a faint aftertaste for me.

path_3.feeling: Well-meaning and polished, but its tidy uplift softens the thornier truths.

path_3.title: Boot, Das (Boat, The) (1981)

path_3.feeling: Featherweight matchmaking farce that left me cold.

path_3.feeling: Glossy uplift I find cloying.

path_3.feeling: Solid, duty-bound western pageantry I respect more than love.

path_3.title: Secret Agent (1936)

path_3.feeling: Acrid familial volleys and repression kept me absorbed.

path_3.feeling: Sharply drawn passions and pressure with satisfying moral contours.

path_3.feeling: Rousing courtroom sparring with sturdy ethical stakes.

path_3.feeling: Elegant, wistful charm that won me over more than expected.
